THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 17, 1930

DUKEHART ELECTED
JUNIOR PRESIDENT
At a meeting of the Junior
class, held in the C. E. Hall,
Wednesday, Ned Dukehart
was elected to succeed himself
as president of the Junior
class. Dukehart presided over
the Sophomore class last year.
The other officers elected by
the Juniors for the coming
year are as follows:
Mettee, secretary.
Bialoskorski, treasurer.
Perry and Becksinski tied
for office of sergeant-at-arms.
There will be a short meeting of the class of '32 to vote
off the tie for sergeant-atarms.

The winner of the Adams Declamation contest, held yearly during
either April or May, is awarded a
gold medal. This competition is
open to only Sophomores. J. K.
Mount, Jr., won the 1929 award.
Senior-Junior Debate
Seniors and Juniors have the opportunity each year to try out for
the respective class debate teams,
composed of three men each, which
meet annually in what is termed the
Herbert B. Adams Debate. The
victorious trio of debaters are permitted to purchase a total of fifty
dollars' worth of books. Last year,
January 16, 1930, the Juniors triumphed over the fourth year men.
When the Freshmen and Sophomores meet to debate, to the victor
goes glory alone. No award is
made in the lower class debate. December 11, 1929, the first year men
—Alpert, Dunn and Milestone—defeated the Sophomore speakers.

THE ROLLINS PLAN
abolish the ten minute provision and
to present the topic to the speaker
TATING on October first with an article by Professor Howard
of Northwestern University, on "Who Ought to Go to College,"
as he enters the entrance to the
The Nation is publishing a series of articles on educational experistage.
ments which should be of interest to Hopkins students. After discussing at length the various methods by which a college may select
the most likely prospects, Dr. Howard shows the hopelessness of the
situation by the following two statements, "Actually, any high school
graduate can enter college, for if one college will not take him, he
can go to another" and "—I am disposed to believe that anybody ought
to go to college who really wants to." In other words, it is impossible to keep any high school graduate out of college and for this reason Dr. Howard advises that everyone who wants to should go to
college.
The foremost defect in this system is stated in the second of the
series of articles, "The Rollins Idea," by Hamilton Holt. Dr. Holt
says, "For in the effort to build up the most elaborate machinery in
the world for turning out academic degrees it seemed to me that we
had somewhere lost the essence of true education, and that to find it
again we must revert to simpler methods, fewer rules, less emphasis
upon information and more upon thinking."
At Rollins for the last four years experiments have been made to
eliminate these defects. The Rollins two-hour conference plan has
obvious advantages. Some of the more important changes are the
abolishment of lectures and recitations, the minimization of term and
yearly examinations, freedom of outside time, and the attempts to
replace textbooks with life that is to say to give nothing second-hand
that may be acquired first-hand by the student.
A teacher presides over each conference but he does not lecture,
nor does he hear recitations. His primary function is to keep quiet, and
to guide and stimulate work. The students study and discuss problems
among themselves. The situation seems ideal for the student who is
really anxious to learn. Furthermore one student who advances more
rapidly than his fellows is not held in check by a slow class. With
the aid of the teacher, he may in the course of a year, cover much
more ground than his classmates. This system, of course, could not
be immediately adopted by American colleges. Some students would
not progress with this lack of rule and regulation. This type of student, however, is the type that needs to be eliminated. The primary
reason why the Rollins Plan could not be adopted is that a sufficient
number of teachers could not be found. One able teacher is needed

HULLABALOO STAFF,
CANDIDATES TO MEET
Candidates and members of
the editorial, art and photographic departments of the
Hullabaloo staff will meet with
Townsend Parks, editor-inchief, in the Hullabaloo office
today at 12:30 P. M. At this meeting Parks will
organize the staff and explain
the year's work. Candidates
are wanted from all classes
for all the departments.
Parks announced that the
work in view will be discussed, but the actual theme
of the book will not be divulgel until later in the year.

The unprecedented growth in the use of die-castings can

largely attributed to the perfection of the process through the

use of gas. Die-casting metal must be kept at constant temperatures for long
periods of time—what better way to maintain the proper thermal head than by
the use of gas? In many cases, too, where intricate dies are involved, tiny gas
jets keep thin sections at uniform temperature, thus preventing the freezing
of metal in the gates, and assuring perfect castings every time.

Nominations for class officers will be held at the first
Sophomore class meeting at
12:20 in C. E. 120 today.
Jack Turnbull, president of
last year's Freshman class, will
conduct the meeting. It is
hoped that as many Sophomores as possible will attend.

Linthicum Named Captain
Of Scabbard and Blade
At the first meeting of the Scabbard and Blade, honorary military
fraternity, it was decided that election for first lieutenant for the ensuing term will be held on Tuesday,
October 21.
Scabbard and Blade is a fraternity to which seniors of high standing in the R. 0. T. C. and other
university activities, as well as
scholarships are elected. There are,
at present, seven men in the company.
Sweester Linthicum, lieutenant
colonel of the Cadet R. 0. T. C.
Corps, automatically became captain of the company due to the fact
that Bledsoe has not returned this
year.
It is planed to have many activities this year, including a dance for
the members.

Coach Morrill Continues
Fall Lacrosse Practice
At the second practice of fall lacrosse, which was held Tuesday,
Coach Morrill, who is in charge,
continued in his elementary drill in
stickwork ann fundamentals for the
candidates. The majority of these
candidates are playing the game for
the first time and this work is a
necessity if they expect to develop
into varsity material. The work for
the main part consisted of passing
and receiving with Coach Morrill
and members of last year's varsity
correcting the new men.
The coach wishes to repeat again
his anouncement to all those who
contemplate trying for the team in
the spring. With many other phases
of the game to be worked and
coached, the man with deficient or
undeveloped stickwork will be at a
distinct disadvantage. It is for the
purpose of teaching and improving
the rudiments of stickwork that the
practice is held in the fall. Men out
for another sport such as football
or cross country, of course, cannot
attend. But those who are able to
participate at this time are urged to
do 50.
Among those of last year's varsity squad who are attending the
practice are Stone, Kelly, Ness, and
McDorman. Others are Davis,
Reid, Mattingly, Martin, Kuper,
Gude, Krulev itch, Chancellor and
Willoughby.
A call for freshman managers in
this sport has also been sent out.
Candidates for this position should
report to Manager L. A. McNeer
at the dressing rooms or the field on
Tuesday and Friday afternoons.

Board To Penalize
Violaters Of Agreement
At a special meeting of the Interfraternity board, Monday, resolutions were passed to the effect that
all violations of rushing rules would
be subject, according to the resolutions, to the usual penalty of from
$1.00 to $100.
So far, the board declared, all
Hopkins fraternities have abided
strictly by the rushing agreement.
The resolutions were passed, however, to acquaint campus fraternal
organizations with just what means
would be used to enforce the agreement.
Rushing regulations prohibit any
fraternity represented by the Interfraternity Board from pledging
Freshmen before the second semester.

ORATORICAL CONTESTS
TO BE HELD AGAIN

VO1

Dr. Wheeler Deplores Lack of
Interest In Events

RU

Declaring there is a decided lack
of interest in the various public
speaking contests sponsored at the
Johns Hopkins University, Dr. Paul
M. Wheeler, of the Department of
English, yesterday stated the oratorical events will again be held this
year, the dates of which have not
been definitely settled.
Dates for the Tocqueville Medal,
the Adams Medal and the Thom
Cup contests; and for the SeniorJunior, Freshman-Sophomore debates will be announced subsequent
to a conference between Dr.
Wheeler and Francis Warlow,
president of the Student Council.
Each speaking event, with the exception of the Thom Cup contention, which is held at night, will be
staged at a weekly assembly of the
student body.
"There is a decided non-interest
among the students in the public
speaking events held on the campus
of the University," declared Dr.
Wheeler. "Frankly, there is no good
reason at all for this absence of enthusiasm toward oratorical contests.
This year, when entrants are called
for there should be a greater response than last."
Dr. Wheeler stated he would
gladly discuss the contests with any
one who is interested in them. His
office is in Remsen Hall, 310.

DUKEHART ELECTED
JUNIOR PRESIDENT
At a meeting of the Junior
class, held in the C. E. Hall,
Wednesday, Ned Dukehart
was elected to succeed himself
as president of the Junior
class. Dukehart presided over
the Sophomore class last year.
The other officers elected by
the Juniors for the coming
year are as follows:
Mettee, secretary.
Bialoskorski, treasurer.
Perry and Becksinski tied
for office of sergeant-at-arms.
There will be a short meeting of the class of '32 to vote
off the tie for sergeant-atarms.

Senior-Junior Debate
Seniors and Juniors have the opportunity each year to try out for
the respective class debate teams,
composed of three men each, which
meet annually in what is termed the
Herbert B. Adams Debate. The
victorious trio of debaters are permitted to purchase a total of fifty
dollars' worth of books. Last year,
January 16, 1930, the Juniors triumphed over the fourth year men.
When the Freshmen and Sophomores meet to debate, to the victor
goes glory alone. No award is
made in the lower class debate. December 11, 1929, the first year men
—Alpert, Dunn and Milestone—defeated the Sophomore speakers.

THE ROLLINS PLAN
abolish the ten minute provision and
to present the topic to the speaker
TATING on October first with an article by Professor Howard
of Northwestern University, on "Who Ought to Go to College,"
as he enters the entrance to the
The Nation is publishing a series of articles on educational experistage.
ments which should be of interest to Hopkins students. After discussing at length the various methods by which a college may select
the most likely prospects, Dr. Howard shows the hopelessness of the
situation by the following two statements, "Actually, any high school
graduate can enter college, for if one college will not take him, he
can go to another" and "—I am disposed to believe that anybody ought
to go to college who really wants to." In other words, it is impossible to keep any high school graduate out of college and for this reason Dr. Howard advises that everyone who wants to should go to
college.
The foremost defect in this system is stated in the second of the
series of articles, "The Rollins Idea," by Hamilton Holt. Dr. Holt
says, "For in the effort to build up the most elaborate machinery in
the world for turning out academic degrees it seemed to me that we
had somewhere lost the essence of true education, and that to find it
again we must revert to simpler methods, fewer rules, less emphasis
upon information and more upon thinking."
At Rollins for the last four years experiments have been made to
eliminate these defects. The Rollins two-hour conference plan has
obvious advantages. Some of the more important changes are the
abolishment of lectures and recitations, the minimization of term and
yearly examinations, freedom of outside time, and the attempts to
replace textbooks with life that is to say to give nothing second-hand
that may be acquired first-hand by the student.
A teacher presides over each conference but he does not lecture,
nor does he hear recitations. His primary function is to keep quiet, and
to guide and stimulate work. The students study and discuss problems
among themselves. The situation seems ideal for the student who is
really anxious to learn. Furthermore one student who advances more
rapidly than his fellows is not held in check by a slow class. With
the aid of the teacher, he may in the course of a year, cover much
more ground than his classmates. This system, of course, could not
be immediately adopted by American colleges. Some students would
not progress with this lack of rule and regulation. This type of student, however, is the type that needs to be eliminated. The primary
reason why the Rollins Plan could not be adopted is that a sufficient
number of teachers could not be found. One able teacher is needed

Nominations for class officers will be held at the first
Sophomore class meeting at
12:20 in C. E. 120 today.
Jack Turnbull, president of
last year's Freshman class, will
conduct the meeting. It is
hoped that as many Sophomores as possible will attend.

Linthicum Named Captain
Of Scabbard and Blade
At the first meeting of the Scabbard and Blade, honorary military
fraternity, it was decided that election for first lieutenant for the ensuing term will be held on Tuesday,
October 21.
Scabbard and Blade is a fraternity to which seniors of high standing in the R. 0. T. C. and other
university activities, as well as
scholarships are elected. There are,
at present, seven men in the company.
Sweester Linthicum, lieutenant
colonel of the Cadet R. 0. T. C.
Corps, automatically became captain of the company due to the fact
that Bledsoe has not returned this
year.
It is planed to have many activities this year, including a dance for
the members.

Coach Morrill Continues
Fall Lacrosse Practice
At the second practice of fall lacrosse, which was held Tuesday,
Coach Morrill, who is in charge,
continued in his elementary drill in
stickwork ann fundamentals for the
candidates. The majority of these
candidates are playing the game for
the first time and this work is a
necessity if they expect to develop
into varsity material. The work for
the main part consisted of passing
and receiving with Coach Morrill
and members of last year's varsity
correcting the new men.
The coach wishes to repeat again
his anouncement to all those who
contemplate trying for the team in
the spring. With many other phases
of the game to be worked and
coached, the man with deficient or
undeveloped stickwork will be at a
distinct disadvantage. It is for the
purpose of teaching and improving
the rudiments of stickwork that the
practice is held in the fall. Men out
for another sport such as football
or cross country, of course, cannot
attend. But those who are able to
participate at this time are urged to
do 50.
Among those of last year's varsity squad who are attending the
practice are Stone, Kelly, Ness, and
McDorman. Others are Davis,
Reid, Mattingly, Martin, Kuper,
Gude, Krulev itch, Chancellor and
Willoughby.
A call for freshman managers in
this sport has also been sent out.
Candidates for this position should
report to Manager L. A. McNeer
at the dressing rooms or the field on
Tuesday and Friday afternoons.

Board To Penalize
Violaters Of Agreement
At a special meeting of the Interfraternity board, Monday, resolutions were passed to the effect that
all violations of rushing rules would
be subject, according to the resolutions, to the usual penalty of from
$1.00 to $100.
So far, the board declared, all
Hopkins fraternities have abided
strictly by the rushing agreement.
The resolutions were passed, however, to acquaint campus fraternal
organizations with just what means
would be used to enforce the agreement.
Rushing regulations prohibit any
fraternity represented by the Interfraternity Board from pledging
Freshmen before the second semester.

ORATORICAL CONTESTS
TO BE HELD AGAIN

VO1

Dr. Wheeler Deplores Lack of
Interest In Events

RU

Declaring there is a decided lack
of interest in the various public
speaking contests sponsored at the
Johns Hopkins University, Dr. Paul
M. Wheeler, of the Department of
English, yesterday stated the oratorical events will again be held this
year, the dates of which have not
been definitely settled.
Dates for the Tocqueville Medal,
the Adams Medal and the Thom
Cup contests; and for the SeniorJunior, Freshman-Sophomore debates will be announced subsequent
to a conference between Dr.
Wheeler and Francis Warlow,
president of the Student Council.
Each speaking event, with the exception of the Thom Cup contention, which is held at night, will be
staged at a weekly assembly of the
student body.
"There is a decided non-interest
among the students in the public
speaking events held on the campus
of the University," declared Dr.
Wheeler. "Frankly, there is no good
reason at all for this absence of enthusiasm toward oratorical contests.
This year, when entrants are called
for there should be a greater response than last."
Dr. Wheeler stated he would
gladly discuss the contests with any
one who is interested in them. His
office is in Remsen Hall, 310.
